Is there a single cinematic hitman who doesn't have a conscience? For a supposedly ruthless profession their blood does run pretty milky in the movies. John Cusack's Martin Blank would rather go gooey over Minnie Driver than cause carnage in Grosse Point. Jason Bourne is as interested in finding himself as your average Goan hippy and even Agent blooming 47, out of a film actually called Hitman, is distracted from his true calling by the love of a good Russian.

So the question has to be asked as to whether "Joe", as played by Nicolas Cage in the remake of the Pang Brothers' 1999 success Bangkok Dangerous, is about to redress the balance. Will he put finally put a touch of dehumanised sadist back into the killer for hire?

0.10: The initial signs are good. Joe, just Joe thank you very much, is sat alone in a diner late on, like some kind of Nighthawk. He is gazing into the distance, contemplating the futility of human existence. We presume.

"My job takes me to a lot of places," Joe intones. "The work is steady, the money's good, but it's not for everyone."

Why's that then? Oh. Is it because you sometimes have to leave what you're doing and, from the top of a tall building, shoot a man dead in the head? That's it, isn't it.

0.19: "My name is Joe ... This is what I do."

Yes, that seems clear now.

0.21: A flash of studio ident and the roar of a jumbo jet signify a jump in the storyline. Joe, it seems, is flying abroad – probably on a job of killing – but where precisely is he going?

"Purposs of your bizit to Bangkok, Mr Lincent?"

"Holiday."

Ah, thanks, helpful customs official! Your inability to say the letter V has clued us right up. We're in the Far East!

0.26:Now we are treated to a montage. This is to confirm, if there had been any doubt, that this film is called Bangkok Dangerous for a reason. First we see a shot of an alluring, mysterious Asian woman (or young man - we're not prejudicial here); then Joe awkwardly attempting tai chi; and, finally, some kick-boxing. We are in Thailand.

0.34: After a motorbike-based murder that proves once and for all that Joe was not telling the whole truth to the customs official, we are once again in the company of a Thai national with stereotypically poor English. He is setting Joe up with his next target, whom he describes thusly: "This guy, he fight bad guys, and helps the poor."

Cue picture of dignitary waving to crowd from seat of convertible like a chubby, Asian JFK.

All the while, Joe's eyes are widening. He's realising, with wearisome predictability, that he's not a cold-blooded killing machine. No, he's a man, with a conscience. Damn.

0.40: What follows now is typical; Joe tells his paymasters he's not happy - "Political assassination wasn't part of the contract" – and lots of shooting, blowing up and nervous looks over the shoulder ensue. At one point Joe constructs a home-made bomb, throws it down some stairs and then hides from the shrapnel in a bath. It's improvisation like that which has taken Joe to the top of his profession.

0.55: The explosions continue as Joe reveals his four rules for a successful career in assassination:

1. Don't ask questions;
2. There is no right and wrong;
3. Don't take an interest in people outside of work (oops!);
4. Know when to get out and walk away rich.

The word "oops" is appended to rule number 3 because Joe's voiceover is spliced with an image of him sitting alone with a beautiful young woman and looking a little soppy. Unless Joe is trying to lure her into a false sense of security before poisoning her with rare mushrooms, it appears rule 3 has been compromised.

1.05: "Nothing is deadlier than a hit man who hits back", reads the tagline, slightly less than convincingly. What about a hitman who isn't compromised by conscience in the first place? Surely they're more dangerous? Or a 50 foot-high lizard that breathes fire?

1.12: No answers are proffered, but we do get some snazzy, slow-mo, stylised action sequences, in order to remind us that this is an Asian action movie, remade by the Pang brothers themselves. One of the brothers calls himself Oxide Pang Chun. His mother must be proud.

1.25: "Well what is your work?" asks an old lady, who is actually quite good with her Rs.

"Banking" replies Joe, with an earnest smile. That's the second time in a minute he's done the ironic What's My Line routine. If you extrapolate that to 90 minutes, we'll have 180 inaccurate job descriptions.

"And why are you here at this top secret mafia hideout?"

"I'm selling buildings insurance"

1.35: The trailer comes to an end in a fury of late-90s electronica (a bit like Chemical Brothers circa Dig Your Own Hole, music fans) and an original, if bizarre, piece of CGI wizardry: namely a shot that pursues a bullet all the way from a rifle into the skull of our AJFK.

It moves fast and the rendering of the scene is convincing. The only thing that's odd is the trajectory of the bullet, which seems to wobble up and down like a new ride at Alton Towers (The Assassin's Bullet). In conclusion, you may not learn much new about the psychology of the hitman, but Bangkok Dangerous promises to be a ballistic bonanza.

It was, we read "a war Russia had not started, had not provoked and had not sought". There was "no other choice but to go to the assistance of those who were being killed". And regretful as they were, people knew it was right, according to the fascinating supplement, Russia, Beyond the Headlines. "I am sorry to say this but I think a lot of western people understand nothing about the situation," said one contributor. "Russia is completely right. Only the blind don't see," observed another. It is fair enough, of course, that the Russian authorities would want to get their point of view across. And it is fair that Rossiyskaya Gazeta, the publication which produced the supplement and is seen as close to the Kremlin, should help to do it. But one does wonder what the readers of Saturday's Daily Telegraph thought of it all when they found the eight-page, Kremlin-friendly pullout tucked within that morning's paper. Some, no doubt, thought it was all a bit rum, especially as the British government has been so critical of the Russian adventure, but perhaps there were others who gained fresh perspective. The Russians tell us they pay the Telegraph £40,000 each month to distribute Beyond the Headlines. At a time like this, that's money well spent.

Gordon Brown will today launch the first phase of his autumn economic fightback when he unveils a package of measures to revive the ailing housing market targeted at first time buyers and vulnerable families.

As the government continued to suffer from the fallout of Alistair Darling's Guardian interview - with the pound falling to a record low against the euro - Brown will try to wrench back control of the political agenda by announcing a three-point plan including a £1bn package to build and acquire more social housing.

Downing Street hopes the plan, to be unveiled at No 10, will focus attention on "real help" for struggling families after a bruising weekend during which the chancellor warned Britain faced "arguably the worst" economic conditions in 60 years.

Launching his housing plan with the communities secretary, Hazel Blears, Brown will announce a £1bn three-point plan which will involve:

· A new mortgage rescue scheme to help the most vulnerable families at risk from repossession.

· A new shared equity scheme aimed at helping first-time buyers, called Home Buy Direct, where government and developers would offer a loan of up to 30%.

· Bringing hundreds of millions of pounds forward to allow social landlords and councils to build more affordable homes.

The housing announcements are the first of a series to be made this week as part of the government's so-called economic relaunch in what has become a defining month for the prime minister. On Thursday he will use what is being billed as a wide-ranging speech to the Scottish CBI to set out further policies to help "hard-working families". September will culminate in a critical speech to Labour's party conference in Manchester.

But Brown's fightback has been overshadowed by Darling's warning about the state of the economy. Some Brown supporters indicated yesterday the chancellor could be vulnerable in a forthcoming reshuffle. But the Brown circle moved last night to quash such rumours when Ed Balls, the schools secretary, told ITV News: "I have no reason to believe there's any prospect in any change of chancellor."

Darling's comments hit sterling, pushing it to a record low against the euro and to its weakest level against the dollar for more than two years.

At one point the pound fell below $1.80 and to 81.40 pence to the euro. Just a month ago the pound would buy $2 and a euro could be bought for 78 pence. Sterling has fallen almost 5% in the past month against a basket of major currencies, and nearly 9% against the dollar.

The government's announcement today on housing comes the day after the Royal Institute for Chartered Surveyors (Rics) reported house sales had reached a 30-year low and figures from the Bank of England put new mortgage approvals for July down 71% on last year.

The government's housing scheme will give a mortgage rescue package to families assessed by a "money adviser" to no longer be able to afford their mortgage repayments.

The package may be of three types - "sale and rent back" which would see a registered social landlord such as a housing association clearing the debt completely, allowing the homeowner to become a tenant at a level they can afford; shared ownership which would see the landlord buying a share (enabling the purchaser to pay off some of their mortgage) and converting the property to shared ownership; and finally shared equity in which a landlord provides a loan for equity, allowing the householder's mortgage repayments to be reduced.

James Rowlands, policy adviser at Rics said that while shared ownership and shared equity schemes were not new, this was the first time the government had allowed the schemes to be offered to those in danger of having their home repossessed.

There's a belief that languages either come naturally to a person, or they don't. But to the late Michel Thomas, the "world's greatest language master", there was no such thing as a bad student, only a bad teacher.

It's a view that grates with prevailing educational opinion. These days, children's inability to learn is often blamed on a variety of learning disabilities. If teachers are brought into the equation, it is usually by ministers either claiming the workforce is the best trained it has ever been, or declaring that inadequate teachers must be fired.

Thomas believed his method, applied faithfully, would work with anyone. Students saw him as a magician. Now, in his new book The Language Revolution, the educational psychologist Jonathan Solity reveals how Thomas set about teaching foreign languages and the psychological principles behind his methods. He thinks they could revolutionise teaching, and help schools meet targets.

Thomas's prowess as a language teacher stemmed from his experiences during the second world war. Born Moniek Kroskof in Poland to Jewish parents in 1914, Thomas was driven by anti-Semitic persecution to France, where he joined the French resistance and spent two years in concentration camps during the war. Having survived interrogation and torture by the Gestapo, he went on to work for the US intelligence services after the war ended, helping to liberate Dachau and convict Nazi criminals by securing secret German documents.

Learning how to block out pain while being tortured unveiled the potential of the human mind to Thomas and the experience proved instrumental in his life's work. He used it to build his new method of teaching languages and set up an institute in Beverly Hills. He taught the rich and famous - Woody Allen, Grace Kelly and Francois Truffaut among them - for money, and gave public classes for free.

Languages were what he chose to teach, but he had more ambitious aims. "I wanted to demonstrate that anybody can learn. I didn't devise my system to teach languages quickly - I did it to change the world." Teaching a language would demonstrate the power of his methods because it was the most "alien" thing for a person to learn, he argued.

Thomas's background meant he struggled to trust anyone throughout his life. He kept his teaching technique secret right up until a decade ago when, in his 80s, he was persuaded by Hodder Education to record it for posterity.

"The language tapes he used in his school were jealously guarded, and kept locked up in his office, as he thought people would steal and corrupt his method," explains Sue Hart, a publisher at Hodder. "His war experiences made him mistrustful of people a lot of the time. Building up his trust was the most difficult thing. We put in a lot of time."

The British public first became aware of Thomas through a BBC documentary, The Language Master, in 1997 (http://uk.youtube.com/watch?v=XQ3xvL22hLE).

He astounded staff at a school in north London by teaching a group of teenagers deemed incapable of learning languages. In one week, they learned the amount of French it normally takes five years to acquire. Three years of careful negotiations later, Hart persuaded Thomas to make recordings with students found through an appeal in Education Guardian. The result was the Michel Thomas Method courses, initially in French, German, Italian and Spanish.

"He never committed anything to paper. He taught without any notes at all. It was an act of faith recording him," Hart says. It paid off. Over a million copies of the language courses have sold so far. And, since Thomas's death in 2005, Hodder has published seven more based on his method, with the help of Rose Lee Hayden, a trusted teacher from his language school.

The tapes are the closest anyone can now get to being taught by Thomas. It is these that Solity has analysed to reveal how Thomas's method works. "Michel said all learning was down to the quality of the teaching, and the teacher rather than the student," he explains.

"He challenged a lot of myths and was absolutely confident his methodology worked not because he was so charismatic - which everyone said he was - but because of the sound psychological principles that underpinned what he was doing. It's likely those principles would extend way beyond teaching foreign languages. This has huge implications for teaching anybody anything."

Proper research

Why, if the method was so foolproof, did Thomas not teach teachers how to teach? He was concerned they would mess about with the formula, Solity says, and his early experiences with education researchers scarred him. "When he was in the States, he did try to negotiate with academics to do some research into his methods. But they weren't willing to do it the way he wanted. He wanted proper scientific research, not the kind where you just go round and ask people what they think works.

"The kind of research that would show why his methods are successful isn't the kind of research educational academics do. They don't compare one method with another, they tend to look at schools that are seen to be effective, and try to pinpoint what it is they have done.

"Even now, in this country, if you think about the literacy and numeracy strategies and all the other initiatives that have been proposed, they've never been piloted in a way that you can say 'this method is more effective than any other'. It's just a kind of hotchpotch of people putting together what they think is a good idea."

This also explains why the sector hasn't embraced Thomas's methods, according to Solity. "People tend to attribute how we learn to some kind of natural ability, and learning difficulties are given as an explanation as to why children can't learn, which is the antithesis of what Michel believed," he says.

Ministers promote teaching that supports the idea that some children have a problem that prevents them from learning, Solity argues. He is convinced Thomas's methods would work in any subject, and improve how all pupils learn. "People think they are either naturals at languages or not, but that's just not the case. If you didn't learn in the past, it's just as likely to have been the fault of a poor teacher.

"Can you imagine a teacher saying: 'Whether or not you learn is down to me. If you don't learn, I'll go home and revise what I'm doing and try to teach you differently.' It's easier to say that children have a learning difficulty," Solity says.

So what psychological principles underpin Thomas's method? Solity says: "Studying in little bits every day is really very powerful, and so is interleaved learning, where you mix the old and the new. It's the idea of teaching a small, core amount of information that's really useful and generalisable. The problem comes when you think teaching more is better - you introduce confusion and that undermines people's capacity to learn."

With Thomas's teaching, students learn comparatively little vocabulary, but do understand how a language is structured. "Michel teaches phrases you wouldn't necessarily use conversationally, but you learn how to put any sentence together. His approach was to learn step by step, very much as we learn English."

Children using the Thomas method are taken to a point where they can retain what they've learned, apply it, and generalise it to other examples. At school, there rarely seems to be time to wait for learning to be embedded in all pupils before moving on. "Thomas's students learned without being aware they were doing so, because of the way he structured knowledge," Solity explains. "He wasn't a Svengali-like figure who seduced them into doing things they wouldn't normally be able to do. He just incorporated these psychological principles."

Transplant sceptic

Chris Husbands, professor of education at the Institute of Education, agrees with the importance of structuring learning. But he's sceptical about transplanting one particular teaching method into all schools. "There's a great desire to find out what works in teaching, but one of the problems with schools and teaching is that almost anything works somewhere. There's a long history of education innovations, which have the power to transform.

"What you typically find is that at the pilot stage, when you have well-trained and enthusiastic pioneers, you get very good results. But when you take it mainstream, you get a wash-out of the effect. Replicating a formula across the whole education system is difficult to sustain, because of the multiple competing goals of education, and the complexity of students and classrooms. If 50 teachers were trained in the Michel Thomas method, you would see a return, but the point at which you get up to 400,000 teachers, you would see a wash-out effect."

Critics suggest that the Thomas's method worked purely because of his personality. Hart hopes the book will prove them wrong. "When Michel taught, he was in his element. It was fascinating to watch. But he used to get very angry when people said it purely because he was so charismatic. We've proved that it was the method that worked."

An advice booklet telling parents how to spot whether their children are involved in a gang and detailing the practical steps they can take is to be published today by the home secretary, Jacqui Smith.

It coincides with the launch of a victim support charity, the New Year Shooting Memorial Trust, set up by Beverley Thomas and Marcia Shakespeare, whose teenage daughters were killed in a drive-by shooting in Birmingham in 2003.

An initial print run of 30,000 copies of the booklet, Gangs: You and Your Child, are to be distributed to inner-city parents in London, Liverpool, Manchester and Birmingham. The initiative comes as the new chief constable of Greater Manchester, Peter Fahy, said he was prepared to use "high-risk tactics" including bringing rival gang members together for face-to-face mediation talks to tackle gun crime.

The relentless pace of gun and knife murders shows no signs of slacking, with two teenage boys, Luke Howard and Shaquille Smith, stabbed to death in Liverpool and Hackney over the weekend. A week before, a young man, Dimitri Foskin, aged 24, was shot dead in Birmingham in the latest in a series of gang-related incidents.

The Home Office booklet for parents contains some apparently obvious signs of gang membership such as finding a weapon hidden among a child's possessions, unexplained physical injuries and withdrawal from family or school life.

More controversial warning signs include wearing a bandana, using a new nickname, using new or unusual slang words or hand signs, and graffiti-style "tags" on possessions, walls or buildings. "Be aware that almost all of [these signs] are normal teenage behaviours and may not indicate gang involvement at all. However, where many of these signs are present, you should take action," says the booklet, drawn up with the help of the Association of Chief Police Officers, parenting organisations and community groups such as Mothers Against Violence.

Parents are advised to be involved in their children's lives, to know their friends and their friends' families, and to encourage them to get involved in positive pastimes and activities.

It reminds parents that girls can be involved too and tells them to be aware of their child's online habits as gangs will often use social networking websites. For those who believe their children are already involved, it recommends seeking help from community organisations that can offer mentoring, mediation, exit programmes and other ways to help them leave the gang.

The home secretary said: "All parents worry about keeping their children safe - and need support to help them to do it. They need to know how to spot if their child is involved in a gang and where to turn to if they are concerned."

Fahy, who was sworn in yesterday as Greater Manchester chief constable, said he was prepared to use imaginative and high-risk tactics to tackle gun crime, with mediation for rival gang members, similar to a scheme in the West Midlands. "You are talking about a group of people who are on the far edge of society and if you are to impact on them you have to be prepared to use imaginative and what may seem high-risk approaches in enforcing the law and dealing with the underlying causes," Fahy said.

He revealed how he had been in danger of straying towards a life of crime as a young man growing up in the East End of London, but had been saved by his inspirational schoolteachers. "If it had not been for one or two teachers I would have been stealing cars."

Japan's beleaguered prime minister, Yasuo Fukuda, resigned yesterday, less than a year after taking office, in a move that threatens to plunge the world's second-biggest economy into political turmoil.

Faced with poor poll ratings, policy deadlock and mounting economic problems, a grim-faced Fukuda said he had decided several days ago to step down to avoid creating a "political vacuum".

Fukuda's resignation leaves the door open for Taro Aso, an outspoken right-winger whom Fukuda made secretary general of the ruling Liberal Democratic party (LDP) in last month's reshuffle.

At a hastily arranged press conference in Tokyo, Fukuda conceded that a recent cabinet reshuffle and the announcement last week of $107bn (£59bn) in extra spending and tax cuts had failed to boost support for his administration.

Faced with an upper house controlled by opposition parties, Fukuda has failed to push through key legislation since he took office last September. Opposition parties, led by the Democrats, have blocked government bills and appointments, including Fukuda's preferred candidate for Bank of Japan governor.

"The power struggle in parliament has caused me many headaches," Fukuda said. "I've tried to talk things through with the opposition, but they have voted against every single important government bill."

Speculation that Fukuda would resign mounted after it became clear that his authority had been badly shaken in a row over the timing of the next parliamentary session. He had wanted parliament to meet last month to vote on the Afghanistan refuelling mission but was opposed by members of his party and the LDP's junior partner, New Komeito, who feared the debate would further damage the coalition's standing.

The government has also been rocked by widespread anger over health insurance reforms that have forced many patients aged over 75 to pay more for medical treatment.

Fukuda's departure promises to bring yet more political instability to Japan. His predecessor, Shinzo Abe, stepped down a year after taking office because of sagging popularity and poor health. Fukuda said: "We can't allow progress to be stalled further, we must not create a political vacuum. Policy must be allowed to move forward so I have decided to step down as prime minister. The Japanese economy and Japanese people's livelihoods are at stake." Fukuda added that he decided to resign before the next parliamentary session begins on September 12.

Despite opposition calls for a snap election, some observers expect the new leader to attempt to rebuild the party's popularity before the next general election is due in September 2009.

A toddler who was accidentally shot in the head with an airgun by his five-year-old sister died in hospital yesterday.

Rashid Ullah had been in a critical condition since the accident on August 24, when the 18-month-old's sister is understood to have shot him with a gun belonging to their father, Bakht Zaman. Zaman, 29, a handyman, had been using the weapon for target practice in their garden in Washwood Heath, Birmingham.

Moments before the fatal accident, he is believed to have reloaded the air gun and turned his back on his children to answer his mobile phone. The children's grandfather, Bakht Rammand, later said that Rashid's sister then took the weapon, pointed it at her brother and shot him.

"Rashid's sister got hold of the gun and pointed it at her brother," he said at the time. "He was on the high ground and she was on the low ground. It hit him right in the middle of the back of his head. Everybody's in shock."

Bakht Zaman and his wife, Fazelat, had been keeping a bedside vigil at Birmingham Children's hospital when their son died.

West Midlands police, who are treating the incident as a "tragic accident", said in a statement last night: "Unfortunately 18-month-old Rashid Ullah died this afternoon as a result of his injuries. Rashid was hurt after he sustained a pellet wound in his head from an air weapon while he was in his garden in Washwood Heath on Sunday."

Rashid's family were too upset to speak last night, but in a statement issued three days after the accident said: "We hope that anyone who has an air weapon realises how dangerous these guns can be and what serious injuries they can cause."

Rashid's death is likely to prompt more calls from campaigners for tighter gun controls. Rammand, 48, has supported the calls. "We are devastated. I am not angry at my son but I am angry that he had this gun in his house," he said after the shooting. "[Rashid's] little sister is too young to know what she has done but she is still very upset and is asking me where her little brother is.

"I think there should be tighter control on guns because it is too easy to buy these airguns."

Most airguns do not require a firearms certificate but since October 2007 it has been illegal to sell an airgun to anyone under 18 and it is an offence to carry an airgun in a public place.

In the aftermath of his shooting, the Gun Control Network, which campaigns for tighter controls on guns of all types, said: "The tragic shooting of the toddler highlights once again the terrible consequences of the 'boys' toys' culture surrounding airgun ownership.

"This culture results in easy access, casual regard and non-accountability. Because airguns are not treated as real weapons they are not thought worthy of registration or regulation.

"They are not taken seriously. The adults who own these guns are rarely held to account. There is no law requiring them to store their weapons safely, nor is there any record of ownership."

The group claimed that airguns were responsible for half of all firearms offences and caused more than a quarter of all serious firearms injuries.

"The government cannot hide behind recent changes in legislation, which failed to take the airgun problem seriously enough and make owners responsible for storing their weapons safely," said Andrew Picken, father of 12-year-old Mitchel Picken, who was killed in 2006 as his friends played with an air weapon. "Airguns and their owners could be registered, and they should be."

Greenpeace climate change activists who scaled one of Britain's tallest power station chimneys, causing £30,000 damage, were accused in court yesterday of crossing the line of acceptable protest.

Five activists, with food and water to stay four days, climbed the 200-metre chimney at Kingsnorth coal-fired power station near Hoo, Kent, last October. They had planned to daub "Gordon, bin it" on the outside of the chimney, but only got as far as painting the name "Gordon" before they came down after 30 hours, a jury at Maidstone crown court heard yesterday.

Huw Williams, 41, from Nottingham; Ben Stewart, 34, from Lyminge, Kent; Kevin Drake, 44, from Westbury, Wiltshire; Will Rose, 29, from London; and Emily Hall, 34, from New Zealand are all charged with criminal damage to the chimney. Tim Hewke, 48, from Ulcombe, Kent, who the prosecution says helped organise the protest from the ground, is also charged with criminal damage. None of them deny causing the damage and they also accept the estimated costs of repairing the damage.

The legality of causing the damage in the first place would be the central issue of the case, said John Price, prosecuting. "These defendants maintain that they had a lawful excuse for damaging the chimney for the protection of other property. Other property, you will hear, in Kent and all around the world. Property said to be at the risk of more serious damage threatened by climate change which is caused by the substantial increase in greenhouse gases of which it is said coal-burning power stations make a large contribution."

But he said the acts committed by the protesters were "not capable of being lawful". He told the jury of nine men and three women that the case was not a prosecution of free speech or legitimate political protest but a prosecution for crossing the line of acceptable protest.

"There are things you can lawfully do in making a protest, but there's a line which has to be drawn," he said.

The activists, who begin their defence today, are expected to argue that they acted to prevent lives being lost and damage being done to properties around the world by global warming. It will be the first time that such a climate change defence has been used in a British court.

The environment group is expected to call leading international climate change academics, researchers and environmentalists as witnesses.

Greenpeace was in a similar situation in 1999 when Lord Melchett, its director at the time, along with others destroyed a field of GM crops in Norfolk. They said in court they were acting to prevent wider environmental damage. The not guilty verdict sent a message to environmental activists that they would not necessarily be punished under the law if they caused damage to property.

The case, which is expected to run a further five days, has extra significance because of public opposition to Kingsnorth power station, and many people have pledged to disobey the law if a coal-fired station is built. More than 2,500 people demonstrated against it last month.

Gordon Brown is expected to give approval to Kingsnorth in the next few months, making it the first new coal-fired station for 30 years. The case continues.

Manchester City supporters reacted with a characteristic blend of cynicism and optimism to yesterday's extraordinary developments at Eastlands, with the overriding emotion one of relief that the controversial tenure of Thaksin Shinawatra was drawing to a close.

Confirmation of the Abu Dhabi United Group's £200m takeover of City, followed swiftly by an astonishing £34m bid for the long-time Manchester United target Dimitar Berbatov, Valencia's David Villa and Stuttgart's Mario Gómez, did not take only the manager Mark Hughes by surprise. City supporters, having spent this summer fretting over the club's financial future and tiring of Thaksin's attempts to flee corruption charges in Thailand, were similarly astounded at their involvement in the most dramatic transfer of deadline day.

Kevin Parker, the general secretary of the Manchester City supporters' club, said: "The takeover sounds very positive and it appears they have very, very deep pockets. While we don't know a great deal about the guy who's fronting the deal, and I suppose we should be cautious after everything that's happened, the reality is he cannot possibly have a past as chequered as the previous owner.

"We all knew the situation surrounding Dr Thaksin and, while I get the impression he'll be involved in the new setup in some capacity, maybe as president, there has been too much bad press about the club recently and it will just be good to get on the back pages again. The fans are happy with what's happening on the field at the moment under Mark Hughes. On the field has been good but it's been a nightmare off it."

Parker believes the Abu Dhabi group will provide the "stability and security" that has been conspicuous by its absence at City recently, with the attempt to steal Berbatov from under the noses of their rivals an impressive statement of intent. "If we get Berbatov, when everyone thought he was going to United, then it could be the most memorable day in the club's history," he added. "Regardless, it has been an unbelievable day. There are no negative feelings about this at all. There are already some supporters down at the stadium dressed as Arabs."

Others, however, had reservations about City remaining under foreign control after a turbulent 14 months under Thaksin. The editor of the King of the Kippax fanzine, Dave Wallace, admitted: "Are we happy about it? The majority of supporters are only concerned with what happens on the pitch. Personally I don't like the idea of Manchester City being owned by Arabs or a former Thai prime minister but that's the way football is at the moment and what the Premier League has allowed to happen.

"Clubs that are owned by one person and heavily in debt wouldn't be allowed in Germany, for instance, but [Roman] Abramovich, the Glazers and now what is happening at City is what the Premier League is about. The traditional fan might not like it but as there are no shareholders at City any more there is nothing we can do about it."

It must be unique for a billionaire's takeover to endear a club to people throughout the land. With the exception of Old Trafford devotees, however, no one could help but smirk yesterday at the thought, which was absurd until mid-morning, of Manchester City attempting to outbid United for Dimitar Berbatov. They would have been beaming in the White Hart Lane boardroom as a yearned-for auction became active at last.

The advent of someone with Sulaiman Al Fahim's resources must also answer the prayers of the City fans, as it would for followers of most other clubs. A trend can seem irresistible and City were already among the nine Premier League members in foreign hands. Of the quartet who usually comprise the top four at the close of each campaign Arsenal are the sole club with a traditional air. Their supporters may now be more unsure than ever about the existing directors, share pact or not, keeping Alisher Usmanov or Stan Kroenke at bay.

The contribution of new proprietors can of course be illusory. Manchester United's means have not, for example, been transformed by the Glazers, who put much of the debt they had incurred on the club's books.

Those who scarcely need to keep track of their money are rare. So far as England is concerned, Roman Abramovich had hitherto been in a category of his own. He may class the money he bestows on Chelsea as loans but, in contrast to the Glazers, the oligarch shows no immediate craving to force the operation to run at a profit.

Abramovich, in addition, was smart because he had identified a club already going places who were relatively cheap to acquire. Shortly before he bought out Ken Bates in 2003, Chelsea had ensured they would be entering the Champions League for a second time.

There is no parallel with City, who have not laid hands on a major honour since the League Cup in 1976. Against such a grey backdrop, the disquieting note yesterday was the emphasis on landing a berth in next season's Champions League. The naming of that target risked instability. That pursuit of Berbatov was meant as a declaration of intent and an indication of the speed at which City would move.

Al Fahim may be courting disappointment in the process. For all the exertions yesterday, hardly anyone can see the existing squad as the equal of Liverpool and Arsenal, let alone Manchester United or Chelsea. No matter what marvels are accomplished in the January transfer window it may be too late to make up lost ground. Any feeling of anticlimax would be ridiculous, but it might still be a cause of turbulence.

Any manager who predates a proprietor typically has grim career prospects, and Mark Hughes will be all the more vulnerable if the expectations of him are steep. It would be terrible for City if he were treated as an element of the old regime that needed to be purged.

Al Fahim, in the manner of Alan Sugar, has his own reality-TV show in which teams of businessmen compete against one another. With luck, that experience will assist him in detecting how impressive the current manager truly is. Over Hughes's three full seasons at Ewood Park, Blackburn Rovers came sixth, 10th and seventh in the Premier League. That was uncanny for a club who attract about 25,000 for the glamorous fixtures. In addition to his control of the side, he achieved that through keen wheeler-dealing and a gimlet eye for a footballer. David Bentley and the Paraguay striker Roque Santa Cruz were foremost among the extraordinary bargains.

From the start, Hughes had shown that he makes outstanding use of whatever resources are placed in his hands. His first managerial post was with Wales and in that five-year spell a 2-1 win over Italy at the Millennium Stadium helped get the national team as far as a play-off with Russia for a berth at Euro 2004.

In view of the results, the rise of Hughes has been slower than it ought to have been but he has had time to hone his approach. City's respectable start, six points from nine, reflects his talent at least as much as Thaksin Shinawatra's funding of signings. Last month Hughes conveyed strength of character when speculation swirled that there would be a fire sale of players, but he also stopped well short of suggesting that he was at war with the club's then owner. He was measured and imposing.

It must be Al Fahim's wish to make City unrecognisable in their new prominence, but to do so he should ensure that the manager continues to be a familiar face.

When the Beatles landed in New York for the first time in February 1964, they were met by 5,000 screaming teenage fans and Jack Hutton. As editor of the Melody Maker, Hutton - who has died aged 80 after a long illness - was in the city to listen to jazz and interview American musicians. His on-the-spot position enabled him to direct the paper's lavish coverage of the first wave of what became known as the British invasion, a phenomenon that was to revolutionise popular music in the US and around the world.

A few weeks earlier Hutton had led a minor revolution of his own, supervising a redesign of the Melody Maker and its simultaneous transfer from the old hot metal production process to the new web offset technology. The new look, brighter and more dynamic, suited the changing mood of the 1960s and helped Hutton in his fight to modernise the paper. He and his reporters had already embraced the arrival of the Beatles, the Rolling Stones and those who followed in their wake with an enthusiasm that gave them an advantage in their circulation battle against the market-leading New Musical Express.

Founded in 1926, the Melody Maker had become known as "the musicians' bible", and Hutton's bold redesign enabled it to brush away the cobwebs lingering from its origins as the house journal of dance bands and crooners. But it was a background in jazz and blues, which Hutton shared with most of his staff, that enabled the paper to establish a strong rapport with the new generation. "You can talk sense to them," Paul McCartney said in 1964.

Among musicians, Hutton's friends and acquaintances were legion. He was able to interview many of those he admired, such as Louis Armstrong, Ella Fitzgerald, Pee Wee Russell and Sidney Bechet, and among his many stories was the one about taking Billie Holiday on a shopping trip to Marks & Spencer where, upon reaching the front of the queue to pay for her purchases, she amazed the assistants and customers by hoisting up her skirt to retrieve a roll of banknotes from her undergarments. He was with the Stones in the Chess studios in Chicago when they recorded It's All Over Now, their first No 1 hit, in 1964.

In later years he became a successful publisher, co-founding a company, Spotlight Publications, that launched several successful music periodicals, including Sounds, Popswap and Kerrang!, during his period as editorial director and later as managing director.

Like most of those with whom he shared the Melody Maker's offices in the 1960s, Hutton had a background in regional newspapers. Born in Sydney, Australia, while his mother and his father, a ship's engineer, were en route home to Scotland, he was brought up in Dundee and joined the powerful locally based publishing firm of DC Thomson at the age of 15. There he worked on the company's highly successful series of weekly comics, including Dandy, Beano and Hotspur. National service with the RAF, where he heard the recordings of the veteran New Orleans trumpeter Bunk Johnson and began a lifelong interest in jazz, was followed by a period back in his home city on the Sunday Post, where he and his fiancee, Joyce Fisker, founded the Dundee Jazz Society.

He and Joyce were married by the time they moved to London in 1954, where he had the choice of jobs with the Daily Sketch, the Evening Standard and the Melody Maker. Accepting the lowest of the three salaries on offer, he began work as a writer and layout subeditor on the music weekly, where the arrival of a shortlived but intense British craze for trad jazz, a simplified form of the New Orleans music that had originally inspired him, brought him into contact with the likes of Acker Bilk, Chris Barber, Kenny Ball, Humphrey Lyttelton, Alex Welsh and Sandy Brown. Hutton had taken up the trumpet during his national service years and played in various amateur bands, often using a cornet given him by Welsh, until illness took hold in his mid-70s.

Taking over as the paper's editor from the long-serving Pat Brand in 1962, he accepted the challenge of attacking the NME on the pop front while maintaining the coverage of jazz, folk and blues that gave the MM a greater credibility among musicians. Thanks to his redesign, and to the careful nurturing of a stable of contributors that included such young pop writers as Nick Jones, Chris Welch and Tony Wilson alongside the jazz critics Max Jones, Bob Dawbarn, Val Wilmer and Bob Houston, the foundations were laid for a campaign that would bear fruit a decade later, when the paper, under his former deputy, Ray Coleman, overtook its chief rival while passing the 200,000 circulation mark.

In 1970, however, with the paper in the ascendant, Hutton and the MM's circulation director, Peter Wilkinson, announced their departure from IPC, the paper's owners, to start a new company with financial backing from City Magazines, owned by the young Rupert Murdoch. The first project was Sounds, a weekly paper devoted to progressive rock and described by Hutton, to those he was attempting to recruit from his former publication, as "a leftwing Melody Maker".

With such writers as Penny Valentine, Steve Peacock and Jerry Gilbert, the paper gradually established itself. The growth proved too slow for Murdoch, however, and Hutton and Wilkinson forged an alliance with Morgan Grampian that was to prove more enduring, allowing them to undertake a number of initiatives. Hutton supervised the fortunes of Music Week, Eve, Over 21 and many other publications until his retirement in 1987.

Sounds closed in 1991, followed into oblivion nine years later by the Melody Maker. But Hutton had left an enduring mark on a singularly exciting period in the history of popular music and on the careers of many young journalists whose talents he encouraged. He became ill in 2003 with tubercular meningitis and died after suffering a chest infection.

Val Wilmer writes: Jack Hutton was a reassuring presence at Melody Maker, which had already been publishing my music photographs. When I began writing about jazz as well as taking photographs it must have been quite a shock to some on the staff. Hutton's friendly paternalism and the encouragement of his fellow Scot Bob Houston helped dampen the worst of the banter.

Hutton hired Penny Valentine to write for Disc, then took her with him to Sounds, using my photographs for its dummy edition. When they were stolen in a burglary targeted at securing such archive material, to reappear as copy-prints sold in Soho, he was very supportive.

In 2003, although clearly unwell himself, he attended Valentine's funeral. "Got to be here for Penny," he insisted, his decency reminding me of another traditional value that existed in Fleet Street back in the day.

· Jack Hutton, journalist and publisher, born April 17 1928; died August 24 2008

Iraqi security forces took control of Sunni Anbar province from the US military yesterday, a milestone in moves to wind down the American presence in a key area that was an insurgent stronghold.

Iraqi troops paraded with flags flying at a formal handover ceremony in the provincial capital Ramadi, once a byword for vicious fighting, though underlying political tensions are yet to be resolved.

"This war is not quite over, but it's being won and primarily by the people of Anbar," declared the US commander, Marine Major General John Kelly. "Al-Qaida has not been entirely defeated in Anbar, but their end is near and they know it. What Anbar needs now, what will end this conflict and prevent al-Qaida from ever coming back, is economic development, reconstruction and funds for compensation."

In Washington President George Bush praised the achievement, saying that the province had been "transformed and reclaimed by the Iraqi people".

Anbar, which is mostly desert, extends from the western outskirts of Baghdad to the borders of Syria, Jordan and Saudi Arabia. It saw some of the bloodiest fighting after the 2003 invasion, including two assaults by US forces on Falluja.

About one third of US fatalities in Iraq, 1,305 troops, have been in Anbar, more than 40% of them by improvised explosive devices.

It is the 11th of Iraq's 18 provinces but the first majority Sunni one to be handed over to the Shia-led Baghdad government.

US forces are to remain but in a limited "overwatch" role in which they will cut back on security patrols and focus on training Iraq's army and police. The US has 28,000 soldiers in Anbar, down from 37,000 in February, while the number of Iraqi soldiers and police has grown to 37,000 from 5,000 three years ago.

The handover is expected to help the US cut troop levels in Iraq at a time when there is pressure to boost forces in Afghanistan, where violence is now worse.

"We would not have even imagined this in our wildest dreams three or four years ago," said the Iraqi national security adviser, Mowaffaq al-Rubaie.

"If we had said we were going to hand over security responsibility from foreign troops to civilian authority people would laugh at us."

The handover had been scheduled for June but was delayed by a row between local leaders and a bomb attack in Ramadi. Anbar was the bastion of al-Qaida in Iraq and its renegade Jordanian leader, Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, who used the area as a staging-ground for attacks in Baghdad until he was killed in a 2006 US airstrike. Two years ago a US intelligence report concluded that al-Qaida had made such inroads that the war was lost in Anbar.

The tide began to turn in late 2006, when Sunni tribal leaders alienated by al-Qaida atrocities changed sides, forming US-funded "awakening councils" that became a model for grassroots guard units across the country.

Security progress after the US troop surge has not been matched by internal political reconciliation. The Iraqi parliament has yet to pass a controversial election law that has been delayed by a dispute over the oil-rich northern province of Kirkuk.

Provincial elections - seen by both Washington and Baghdad as a key development - can be held this year only if agreement can be reached in the next two weeks.

Undoubtedly the media must take a large share of the blame for the MMR debacle (MMR was the biggest science story in years - and a hoax, August 30), but the biggest culprit must surely be the government. This would almost certainly have meant that the story would have been forgotten within a few weeks.

However, the government's panic reaction was to rubbish the findings and, more especially, to try to smear Dr Wakefield. It then compounded its errors by refusing to make separate vaccinations available. Hence, the public, spurred on by the media, assumed that there was indeed something to hide, with the resultant disastrous reduction in the take-up of vaccination.

Forensic scientists were last night studying the remains of a third body found in the burnt-out Shropshire mansion of the millionaire businessman Christopher Foster. The remains were discovered across the hall in the main part of Osbaston House from the gutted front room, where teeth and bone fragments of Jill Foster, 49, and an unidentified man were found at the weekend close to a 0.22 rifle.

Detectives have upgraded the original arson investigation into a murder inquiry, but are not yet confirming that Christopher Foster, 50, and his 15-year-old daughter, Kirstie, are the two unknown victims at the isolated house near Maesbrook hamlet. A round-the-clock search is continuing.

The family was last seen returning to the 15-acre estate after a barbecue at a Shropshire car dealer's home a week last night. Friends of Kirstie, who was due to return to her boarding school at nearby Ellesmere this week, said she had abruptly left an internet chat in the early hours.

Foster's oil rig insulation business faced debts of more than £1m. His flamboyant lifestyle, with two Porsches and an Aston Martin in the ruined stableblock, went with business practices which a high court judge described this year as "bereft of the basic instincts of commercial morality".

West Mercia police, which has more than 100 officers on the case, said it could not confirm reports that court bailiffs had arrived at the house on Tuesday morning to find it devastated and sealed off. County courts at Oswestry, five miles away, and Birmingham had no comment on the claim.

Detective Superintendent Jon Groves said removal of the third set of remains would "take time because of its position". Identification of the man's remains and cause of death is also proceeding slowly.

"We had the [third set of] remains confirmed as human late last night by a Home Office pathologist and we are hoping to get the body out by the end of Monday, with a postmortem taking place either Monday night or Tuesday," he said. "A forensic archaeologist is due to visit the site to offer specialist advice."

Officers are having to work gingerly beneath shored-up walls stripped of plaster by the fire. The site has had to be evacuated several times after further debris fell.

Detectives have established that Mrs Foster, whose 4x4 with the number plate JILL40 was also destroyed, was shot through the head. Autopsies have been carried out on the remains of Kirstie's three horses, Scrumpy Jack, Breezy and Bramble, which she described on the internet site Bebo as central to her life. They had been shot, along with the family's four dogs.

Friends of the family visited the edge of the garden at Osbaston House yesterday to leave flowers. Fiona Bray, whose daughter Megan clung to her tightly as they passed the police cordon in a single-track lane, said: "We have heard things said about the Fosters that are just not true. We have come to pay our respects because Megan went to school with Kirstie and we were very close to the family. They were a lovely bunch of people."

Police are still examining the remains of a CCTV security system found at the house and what is left of two computers. Spent and unspent gun cartridges found in the grounds are also being checked and fingerprint and DNA specialists are working on the family's horsebox, which was left with its tyres punctured in front of the main electronic gates.

Kirstie's headmaster, Brendan Wignall, said everyone at her school was "deeply concerned" by the discovery of the third body. He said: "Despite the obvious speculation, I feel that it would be inappropriate to comment further but we are all deeply concerned about this latest development in the ongoing investigation."

The School-Home Support Service is an independent charity that provides support workers in schools across the UK. I'm based in a secondary, but also work with the feeder primaries, supporting families where there are issues that are getting in the way of children's learning.

Often teachers might identify that there is something going on at home, but where they don't have the time to investigate it, I can. It might be domestic violence, housing, behaviour, debt - the whole range of issues.

Because we are not part of social services and we're independent of the school, parents are often more open to talking to us and trust us more. We are all about early intervention, so we work with families who probably don't meet the threshold for social services. We have the time to spend listening to parents, and we have the knowledge and background to signpost organisations and services within the borough.

Part of our role is meeting parents in the playground, running coffee mornings and parenting classes. Parents often self-refer, or a teacher will ask if they would like us to ring. I spend some of my days doing home visits and I give parents the option to meet at home or at school or even in a café, somewhere neutral - not everyone wants me popping round. If they meet me at school and get to know me, then they may invite me round.

The best bit of my job is building relationships with parents and getting to know them and their children. It can be a very empowering experience for parents. When you first meet they may not have that much confidence, but after a few sessions, or after coming to parenting classes, they are brimming with it: some have gone on to university or back to work. And those sorts of things make a big difference to families.

It's no good, I have to come clean. I felt guilty the moment I wrote it down, and now I need to put things right. In an earlier column (June 3), I wrote "the most common number of readers for academic papers, once published, is zero". This was subsequently quoted on the letters page (June 7). Well, I have always considered myself a bit of a purist about statistics, and keep a very high horse for times when I need to look down on other people's misuse. So, with great regret, I have to clamber into the saddle to pour scorn on myself.

In partial defence, I did say that this is something I had heard, and didn't know whether it is true, or how it was possible to tell. But in fact it is almost certainly true, and we can know so without even doing any studies. Most people will have come away with the impression that I was suggesting that more papers go unread rather than read. My confession is that all along I knew that what I said doesn't mean this at all.

Let me explain. Of all the papers ever published, some will have been read perhaps tens of thousands of times, others thousands, and all the way down the scale to zero. Maybe you can see where this is heading. It seems unlikely that the most common number of readers is going to be, say, 1,352. Small numbers are likely to come up more often, and the most likely of all is probably zero, even if that is only a tiny fraction of all papers. So the most common number of readers may be none. Big deal.

So continueth today's lesson, on the ambiguity of the concept of "average". Remember that it used to be said that the average family in the UK had 2.4 children? That made us all giggle (especially those of us who thought we knew someone who could be counted as 0.4). But of course this was the average in the sense of the mean: take the total number of children in all families and divide it by the number of families. QED.

But there are other concepts of average, too, the median and the mode. The median is "the one in the middle". So the median number of children in families in the UK now is probably two. If you line up all families, with those with no children at one end, and those with loads and loads at the other end, the family in the middle probably has two.

The mode means "most common" number. Looking at these families again, it may well be that the most common number of children is two, but then it might be one or zero (as in the case of the journal papers). So averages are tricky and shifty. When the mean, mode and median come apart, don't risk your money.

And there are so many examples. A while ago I heard it reported that 90% of men thought that they were of above-average athletic ability. What typical male vanity! How can more than 50% of people be above-average anything? Well, very easily, actually, if by average we mean "mean" rather than "median". Ask yourself: what is the mean number of legs possessed by human beings? Bearing in mind that, very sadly, a small number of people have a single leg, or none at all, the answer is something like 1.9999. Therefore, almost everyone has an above-average number of legs.

In Lake Wobegon, so Garrison Keillor told us, the women are strong, the men are good-looking, and the children are all above average. Industrial disputes are hardly welcome news but the authors of a new report on the changing status of further education lecturers could be forgiven some grim satisfaction over battles brewing at two colleges.

The University and College Union is bracing itself for a scrap at Bishop Auckland College in county Durham, where the management says a looming financial crisis is forcing it to seek a change in contracts for all teaching staff.

And at Coleg Menai in north Wales, lecturers have voted to take part in industrial action in a dispute over class sizes and teaching hours, which UCU is billing as a defence of educational quality and professional standards.

Whatever the rights and wrongs in these situations, each surely chimes with the core thesis of the report by three academics specialising in industrial relations and management, that the increasingly market-oriented approach in further education demanded by government has diminished the professional status of teachers in colleges.

Nowhere in the public sector has the pace of change been more rapid than in further education, triggered by the "incorporation" of colleges in 1993 and their independence from local authorities, argue Kim Mather, Les Worrall and Roger Seifert.

The result, they say, is that teaching in further education has been degraded and deskilled. Lecturers are increasingly directed by managers who are as interested in achieving efficiency as in the education of students.

Although concepts such as inspirational leadership and empowerment are talked up in management literature, the reality for further education lecturers appears to be "increased centralised control, reduced autonomy, job degradation, cost reduction and strategies to improve productivity by intensifying the utilisation of labour", say the report's authors, all senior academics at Midlands universities.

Lecturers' ability to decide what they teach and how has been eroded. In some cases management has started to see lecturers almost as interchangeable units. At one Midlands college where the authors conducted their research they found a philosophy lecturer timetabled to teach basic skills to trainee hairdressers.

Lecturers forced into such situations complain of little time to prepare for unfamiliar subjects. They resent teaching from "instructor packs" and using materials that they have had no hand in designing.

But perhaps the most undermining aspect of being shoved from subject to subject is, they feel, the lack of regard for their expertise in their own discipline. One theory considered by the report is that further education lecturers have been particularly vulnerable to reform. They have lacked professional recognition historically, partly because they are such a diverse bunch with such a wide range of prior professional experience, particularly among those teaching vocational subjects.

But it is not all the managers' fault. Some lecturers blame government for an approach that puts business efficiency over education and regards students as customers. "FE management is not about helping students learn - it is about obeying the threats of a series of governments, which have neither understood, nor loved, FE," one lecturer told the authors. And here there is probably common ground between lecturers and management.

Bishop Auckland College has been forced to seek changes in contracts with 305 teaching and support staff because dramatic funding changes brought in by government have helped push up staffing costs to an unsustainable level, says its principal Joanna Tait. According to a regional UCU official, Joyce McAndrew, the college is trying to force its staff to accept inferior working conditions without proper negotiations. Tait says she has "absolutely no intention of changing terms and conditions without full and proper consultation".

The government's insistence on colleges competing for ever more of their funding is putting more pressure on management, she says. Colleges are like hospitals, which lose so many beds in the name of efficiency that they are no longer able to cope with major crises.

"The tension we have to live with is that we are supposed to be infinitely flexible - dropping everything to do something tomorrow - but at the same time we need to have some steady core," she says.

"I am very much opposed to the introduction of market values into the management of FE because I don't think it fits at all well, but we have to live in a system where we are being asked to promote ourselves in this way."

· The Changing Locus of Workplace Control in the English Further Education sector, by Kim Mather, Les Worrall & Roger Seifert, will be published in Employee Relations journal

Their patches back on to each other, divided by a difference in postcode - B6 and B21 - and the A34 Birchfield Road. Catch yourself on one side of the dividing line and you are in Burger Bar Boy turf, step across it and suddenly you are in the Johnston Gang's manor. Transgress into the wrong territory, get spotted and you could be history.

This is the reality on the troubled streets of Birmingham's Lozells, Handsworth, Newtown and Aston areas, thickly populated, socially deprived inner city estates that have been peppered by the bullets of gang warfare for more than a decade. The killing of Dimitri Foskin, 24, last month near his home in Newtown brought Birmingham and its gangs attention not seen since two young women, Letisha Shakespeare, 17, and Charlene Ellis, 18, were killed in the crossfire at a party outside an Aston hairdresser's early on New Year's Day 2003. In the year that they had just celebrated passing, the war between the Burgers and the Johnstons claimed 27 young lives.

In the last month in Birmingham, there have been two drive-by shootings, a fatal stabbing and the killing of Foskin. Now police and community activists are trying to piece these events together and see if they have a common thread: of revenge and retaliation. Kirk Dawes, a former police officer who now runs the West Midlands Mediation and Transformation Service, said: "We try to conflict-map it, find out what was the catalyst for this behaviour, find out whether it goes back all the way. What happened in the past is the issue and that is what's going to drive it. It's a nonsense that they are killing to move up the ranks or earn stripes within their gang. It's because 'they did it to my friend or my brother or whatever'. Within the black community, issues of respect play a fantastic part in all of this. Something happens and they think 'we have got to back him' and it causes gang warfare."

Where the gangs began in Birmingham is open to debate, but in the 1990s the biggest networks were the Burgers (named after the burger joint they hung out in in Soho Road) and the Johnstons, aka Johnnies and JC, (named similarly after a cafe, in Heathfield Road). Aside from bullets, the gangs dealt in crack cocaine and created a kind of carnage the city had never seen. Soon enough, they had smaller crews affiliated to them - the Badder Bar Crew, the Bang Bang Crew, the Cash or Slash Money Crew and the Raiders, to name just four. Dawes said the groups could be based on postcode. "When you have one violent incident after another, people feel the need to take sides. That's what we are seeing now."

The New Year's Day killings - which can be traced back to the murder of Yohanne Martin, a key Burger, in December 2002 - led to the conviction of a number of gang "kingpins" and many of the more senior members moved into the shadows. This, say some, has created a vacuum into which younger, more chaotic, less disciplined gang members have moved, though Dawes says there are still 400 proper gang players in Birmingham.

Dr Derrick Campbell, chair of the National Independent Advisory Group on Criminal Use of Firearms, which liaises with the Home Office, said: "When the individual leaders were taken out of the system we had a lot of splinters. Now there is a lack structure, people are trying to find their own way forward and they are jockeying for position.

"You have people walking around with bulletproof vests and guns wanting to exact revenge. There is no sense of management and control. That's what makes it even more scary." Campbell says this has been made worse by cuts in grants for agencies working to tackle the roots of the problem.

"Evidence shows that organisations that have been delivering a very good service, engaging the confidence and trust of young people, and black young people in particular, those organisations have lost funding and those young people have gone back into criminal activity."

A rapper named Witness, born Adrian Burke, who uses his lyrics to tackle issues such as gun crime and sits on the Birmingham Reducing Gang Violence Group says gangs attract young black men who have mostly grown up in fatherless households and are looking for identity and significance.

"They seem to have some sort of loving there in the gangs. What is scary now is that children as young as five and six are talking to me and what they have seen in their brother's bedroom is not porn, it's guns. They are telling me about gangs. It's becoming a culture, with young kids at junior school representing their gangs, 10-year-olds pledging allegiance to gangs who can tell you in intimate detail what's going on in the street, talking about Glocks and semi-automatic hand pistols," he said.

"These kids suffer from mental health issues, low self-esteem, trauma from seeing people being shot in front of them. And the younger the lieutenants get, the more dangerous it is going to get. It's moved from behaviour to culture. I have been nervous before, but it is starting again. And it's scary."

Gordon Brown's inner circle moved last night to close ranks in support of Alistair Darling after signs of a fall-out between 10 and 11 Downing Street prompted a dramatic fall in the value of the pound.

Hours after authoritative government sources indicated Darling could be vulnerable in the next reshuffle, the PM's closest cabinet ally indicated that the chancellor's position was safe. Ed Balls, the schools secretary, told ITV News: "I have no reason to believe there's any prospect in any change in the chancellor ... I think it would be the wrong thing to do."

But Balls indicated continuing irritation with David Miliband, weeks after the foreign secretary sparked speculation about his leadership intentions with a Guardian article on how Labour should launch a fightback. Balls observed cabinet convention by saying that Miliband was not challenging the prime minister, but he pointedly warned that to do so would be "crazy, destructive and divisive".

The former chief economist at the Treasury, Brown's closest aide until he stood for parliament in 2005, spoke as the fallout from Darling's Guardian interview over the weekend was in danger of spiralling out of control. Brown's deep irritation over Darling's gloomy take on economic conditions was reflected in an authoritative briefing in yesterday's Times that the chancellor was "wrong" and had damaged his position. Darling told the Guardian that some people had their eye on his job or were actively trying to do it, which some saw as a veiled reference to Balls.

But last night Balls said: "I don't want his job. What I want to do is get on with the job I'm doing. We've got rising primary and secondary school standards."

But he highlighted one area where Brown was particularly irritated by the reporting of Darling's interview: the suggestion Britain alone was suffering the worst economic conditions in 60 years. Downing Street accepts Darling made clear to the Guardian that he was warning that the world is facing economic downturn, though they believe the chancellor was not clear enough. Balls said: "It's important to get the balance of that message."

The intervention by Balls shows the balance of power in the cabinet has changed in the wake of Darling's interview. The chancellor is weakened in the eyes of the Brown circle but the fallout from his interview means it would be difficult, if not impossible, to remove him. The Tories say they would accuse the Brown of "sacking the chancellor for telling the truth."

The appearance of a rift in Downing Street will strengthen the hands of ministers and backbenchers who believe the prime minister needs to go. A tiny group, dubbed the Blairite Taliban, want Brown to go immediately. But a broader group believes he should be given a clear run until parliament returns next month, after the party conferences, to revive his premiership. If he fails to dent the Tory poll lead by winter, then they expect him to face intense pressure.

A senior Labour MP said there could be an "orderly" move against Brown involving one or more members of the cabinet. Failing that, it would be "disorderly", with a revolt from those backbenchers most anxious about losing their seats.

What next for the PM?

Cabinet Brown will want to show that he commands the confidence of and is wholly supportive of his cabinet.

Labour conference The prime minister will need to persuade a sceptical party and public that he is capable of leading them out of the economic and political crisis. His performance over the next month is likely to determine whether he survives.

Byelection The death of John MacDougall, MP for Glenrothes, means the PM faces another difficult byelection. Labour last night selected the headteacher of Brown's former school, Lindsay Roy, 59, to fight the seat. No 10 is expected to wait until after Labour's conference before defending the seat.
